item.title: Bankruptcy Abuse Prevention and Consumer Protection Act of 2004

latestAction.text: Message on House action received in Senate and at desk: House amendment to Senate bill and House requests a conference.

item.text: Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On agreeing to the resolution Agreed to by voice vote. (text: CR H144)
Passed/agreed to in House: On agreeing to the resolution Agreed to by voice vote.(text: CR H144)
The previous question was ordered without objection.
DEBATE - The House proceeded with one hour of debate on H. Res. 503.
Considered as privileged matter. (consideration: CR H143-148)
Placed on the House Calendar, Calendar No. 141.

It shall be in order to consider as an original bill for the purpose of amendment under the five-minute rule an amendment in the nature of a substitute consisting of the text of H.R. 975 as passed by the House. If the Senate bill, as amended, is passed, then it shall be in order to move that the House insist on its amendment to S. 1920 and request a conference thereon.
The House Committee on Rules reported an original measure, H. Rept. 108-407, by Mr. Sessions.
The House Committee on Rules reported an original measure, H. Rept. 108-407, by Mr. Sessions.

summary.text: Sets forth the rule for consideration of the bill (S. 1920) to extend for 6 months the period for which chapter 12 of title 11 of the United States Code is reenacted.

(This measure has not been amended since it was introduced. The summary of that version is repeated here.)

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
